sn22.94:1.2: “Bhikkhus, I do not argue with the world; it is the world that argues with me.
sn22.94:1.3: When your speech is in line with the Dhamma, you do not argue with anyone in the world.
sn22.94:1.4: What the wise deem as not existing, I too say does not exist.
sn22.94:1.5: What the wise deem as existing, I too say exists.
sn22.94:2.1: And what do the wise deem as not existing, which I too say does not exist?
sn22.94:2.2: Form that is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.
sn22.94:2.6: Consciousness that is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable.
sn22.94:2.7: This is what the wise deem as not existing, which I too say does not exist.
sn22.94:3.1: And what do the wise deem as existing, which I too say exists?
sn22.94:3.2: Form that is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.
sn22.94:3.4: Consciousness that is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.
sn22.94:3.5: This is what the wise deem as existing, which I too say exists.
sn22.94:4.1: There is a mundane phenomenon within the world that the Realized One awakens to and comprehends.
sn22.94:4.2: Having done so, he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.
sn22.94:5.1: And what is that mundane phenomenon within the world?
sn22.94:5.2: Form is a mundane phenomenon within the world that the Realized One understands and comprehends.
sn22.94:5.3: Having done so, he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.
sn22.94:6.1: This being so, what can I do about a foolish ordinary person, blind and sightless, who does not know or see?
sn22.94:6.5: Consciousness is a mundane phenomenon within the world that the Realized One understands and comprehends.
sn22.94:6.6: Then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it.
sn22.94:7.1: This being so, what can I do about a foolish ordinary person, blind and sightless, who does not know or see?
sn22.94:8.1: Suppose there was a blue water lily, or a pink or white lotus. Though it sprouted and grew in the water. Having risen up above the water, it would stand unsmeared by the water.
sn22.94:8.2: In the same way, though the Tathāgata was born and grew up in the world, he abides having surmounted the world, unsmeared by the world.”
